Award.AwardTitle: Development of methodological framework for effective deployment and operational optimization of flexibly automated production and service systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Development of a methodological framework for the effective deployment and the operational optimization of flexibly automated production and service systems

The quest for an ever increasing level of automation is a prevailing trend in many sectors of the modern economy, ranging from the contemporary production systems and their supporting material handling systems, to the various intelligent transportation systems that are currently employed or contemplated for the future transport needs, to the internet-based workflow management systems that have been proposed for the mechanization of various routine operations taking place in service sectors like banking, insurance claiming, and the backend transactions of contemporary logistics systems. However, the existing theory for supporting the deployment and the real-time management of such automated operations in the aforementioned application contexts is challenged by the operational complexity and the large-scale nature of these applications. Hence, the proposed research program seeks to develop a novel methodological framework that will address the currently perceived needs with respect to the aforementioned task. More specifically, the successful implementation of the proposed program will enable a more streamlined and a more robust deployment of the sought automating capability and it will help in materializing the operational flexibility and efficiency that have been contemplated for the corresponding environments.

From a methodological standpoint, the proposed research program will abstract the aforementioned operations as a class of resource allocation systems (RAS) that must be controlled for operational safety, behavioral correctness / logical consistency, and eventually performance. More specifically, the proposed research program will leverage the existing theory of RAS supervisory control developed by the PI and his collaborators, and it will complement this theory with the necessary performance-oriented control / scheduling theory that will lead to the complete development of a real-time control framework for the considered RAS. The proposed developments will also be based on an effective integration of qualitative and quantitative DES theory in the context of the existing RAS, and they will further provide pertinent approximating schemes that can support an effective and systematic trade off between the operational efficiency of the derived control policies and their computational tractability. In fact, it should be noticed that the pursued methodology for the aforementioned integration of DES qualitative and quantitative control in the context of the considered application is a substantial contribution to the field of DES theory itself, since, historically, and in an effort to effectively manage the underlying analytical complexities, these two major DES areas have evolved on parallel tracks. Also, when viewed from the standpoint of scheduling theory, the proposed research program seeks to develop effective and efficient scheduling policies for what can be perceived as stochastic networks with blocking, a topic that has not been extensively investigated by the current scheduling theory due to the involved complexity. On the other hand, it is expected that the aforementioned grounding of the proposed research on qualitative and quantitative DES analysis and the effective integration of these two areas, will provide the necessary analytical and computational tools for the effective management of this complexity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From a systemic perspective, many of the challenges related to the support and delivery of the extensive levels of operational efficiency, flexibility and autonomy that are requested and/or envisioned for many contemporary applications, essentially boil down to the effective real-time management of a finite set of resources that are contested by concurrently executing processes. This resource allocation problem arises, for instance, in the operational context of many flexibly automated production and distribution systems, various automated/autonomous transportation systems, the internet-enabled workflow management systems that are currently promoted in various parts of the service sector like banking, insurance claims and (e-)commerce, and the multi-threaded software that is supported by the current multi-core computer architectures. In the automated operational context of all these environments, the underlying resource allocation must be controlled not only for operational efficiency, but also for logical correctness. In particular, the system controller must ensure that all of the running processes must be able to acquire the necessary resources and proceed to their completion in a timely manner, while avoiding potential deadlocks and/or livelocks.

The resulting scheduling problem is highly complex, and its effective resolution necessitates a profound understanding of the underlying structure and dynamics, and of the impact of this structure and dynamics on the emergent performance. In addition, any practical solution to these problems must be computationally tractable within the stringent time budgets that are defined by the real-time nature of the considered operations. Some ways that have been pursued by the corresponding scientific and engineering communities in their effort to master all this conceptual/analytical and computational complexity, are (i) the decomposition of the overall scheduling problem to some simpler components, and (ii) the employment of the results and insights that are obtained from this analysis towards the establishment of a systematic and controllable trade-off between the operational efficiency of the synthesized solutions and their computational tractability.

The cosidered research program has capitalized upon a pre-defined decomposition of the aforementioned scheduling problem, and a set of pre-existing results for some of the subproblems that were specified by this decomposition, in order to develop an integrated solution methodology for the overall scheduling problem, that also possesses the desirable properties that were specified in the previous paragraph. In this way, it has addressed an essential gap in the corresponding scheduling theory, and it enables in a substantial manner the pursuance of the combined objective of efficiency, flexibility and autonomy that have been aspired for the target applications that were listed in the opening paragraph.

At the same time, the project has trained a number of graduate students who were employed as research assistants in the corresponding methodologies, and in the advancement of these methodologies through work leading to Ph.D. dissertations. In addition, the derived results have been further disseminated through journal publications, conference and invited seminar presentations, and the PI's participation in a number of summer schools.

Finally, an additional important value of this project lies in the demonstration and promotion of the potential that is held by rigorous mathematical modeling and analysis as a very powerful means for tackling effectively and systematically some of the most challenging problems that are posed by the current technological trends and developments.
